name: Rona Carter
title: Associate Professor of Developmental Psychology
description: Research examines how off-time pubertal development affects the mental health, behavior, and education of Black girls and other youth of color.

name: Cole Nogawa
title: Lab Assistant
description: Interested in the roles of racial and ethnic identification in determining mental health outcomes, particularly adolescent depression.

name: Joonyoung Park
title: Doctoral Student
description: Interested in how society and parents convey information about puberty to adolescents.

name: Susan Gelman
title: Heinz Werner Distinguished University Professor
description: Professor of Psychology and Linguistics at University of Michigan

name: Sabina Li
description: Received a B.S. in Biopsychology, Cognition and Neuroscience and in Evolutionary Anthropology from the University of Michigan in 2025.

name: Lauren Girouard-Hallam
description: Broadly interested in how children use novel technologies to think and learn about the world around them. Current research explores whether children trust generative AI chatbots like ChatGPT.

name: Kayley Dotson
description: Broadly interested in studying young children’s social cognition and cooperation.

name: Sandra Graham-Bermann
title: Professor of Psychology
description: Research focuses on the impact of family violence on children, using ecological theory, trauma theory and relationships theory.

name: Arianna Gard
title: Assistant Professor of Developmental Psychology
description: Her research examines the neurobiological mechanisms linking socioeconomic adversity and protective factors to youth socioemotional development.

name: Omid Kardan
title: Assistant Professor
description: His research focuses on the relationship between environmental factors, functional brain architecture, and cognitive and mental health outcomes.

name: Melissa Peckins
description: Her research utilizes a multi-level, interdisciplinary approach to study how contextual factors such as child maltreatment and violence.

name: Natasha Jones
title: Data Manager
description: She is currently working as a data manager for the Michigan Twins Neurogenetics Study.

name: Allison LaMonica
title: Staff Coordinator
description: She enjoys learning about the underlying processes behind mental disorders.

name: Hannah Dees
title: Project Coordinator
description: She is interested in studying adverse childhood experiences and their effects on biological and behavioral development.

name: Ioulia Kovelman
title: PhD
description: Laboratory Director

name: Aleksandra Witkowska
description: Project Coordinator

name: Ziqian Shen
description: Data Management

name: Min-Ying Wang
description: Recruitment Manager

name: Christopher Monk
title: Developmental Psychology Program at the University of Michigan

name: Sunghyun Hong
description: Her research questions include examining the effects of complex trauma on the neuroscience of resilience and identifying socio-cultural protective factors buffering risks of living in disadvantaged social contexts.

name: Linda Zhang
description: Linda is broadly interested in the impact of early life experiences and environment on brain development. In particular, she’s interested in changes in neural functioning related to reward processing and executive functioning, and the implications on psychopathology and behavioral outcomes.

name: Ryan Tung
description: His research questions include examining how measures of biological aging developed using DNA methylation are associated with the organization of brain networks and their implications on adolescent psychopathology.

name: Sahvannah Michaud
description: Sahvannah’s research focuses on the impact of childhood adversity on neurodevelopmental trajectories, particularly in cognitive and emotional domains. Her work also explores the mechanisms of risk and resilience associated with these early life experiences and how they may contribute to the development of anxiety and depression during adolescence and early adulthood.

name: Deborah Rivas-Drake
title: Stephanie J. Rowley Collegiate Professor of Education and Professor of Psychology
description: Examines how school, peer, family, and community settings can support adolescents in navigating issues related to race and ethnicity, and how these experiences inform young people’s academic, socioemotional, and civic development.
lab_name: Contexts of Academic + Socioemotional Adjustment (CASA) Lab

name: Paige Bost
description: Studies the psychology of prejudice, particularly in regards to race and ethnicity. Interested in how White children are socialized to understand race in their families, communities, and through educational contexts.
lab_name: Contexts of Academic + Socioemotional Adjustment (CASA) Lab

name: Saraí Blanco Martinez
description: Conducts community-engaged, participatory action research to better understand how to better support the efforts of Latinx immigrant-origin young people to heal from experiences of racism and discrimination.
lab_name: Contexts of Academic + Socioemotional Adjustment (CASA) Lab

name: Victoria Vezaldenos
description: Interested in exploring ethnic-racial identity development processes for Multiracial adolescents and young adults. Aims to develop a reliable measure of critical Multiracial ethnic-racial identity.
lab_name: Contexts of Academic + Socioemotional Adjustment (CASA) Lab

name: Oluwaseun Oyindamola Ogunleye
description: Research focuses on Black migratory bodies through an Afrocentric lens. Committed to fostering transborder solidarity in schools.
lab_name: Contexts of Academic + Socioemotional Adjustment (CASA) Lab

name: Wendy de los Reyes
title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow
description: Work is contextualized by her identity as an immigrant, a Latina, and a first-generation college student. Focuses on the healthy development of immigrant-origin adolescents.

name: Rosario Ceballo
title: Associate Dean for Social Sciences, Professor of Women’s Studies and Psychology
description: Research investigates how contextual aspects of living in poverty, such as exposure to community violence, influence children and adolescents’ academic and psychological functioning. Focuses on Latino families and the experience of infertility among racial minority women.

name: Lilia Cortina
title: University Diversity and Social Transformation Professor of Psychology, Women’s & Gender Studies, and Management & Organizations
description: Investigates the many ways in which people are subordinated, violated, and relegated to the margins of organizational life. Focus on sexual harassment and workplace incivility.

lab_name: Organizational and Community Multicultural Praxis Lab

name: Mari Kira
title: Faculty member
description: Explores adult psychological growth that can emerge from struggles with work-related adversities. Also explores the meaning of wellbeing in the context of adversarial life circumstance and the strategies and resources that foster people’s wellbeing in such situations.

name: Evita Schäfer
description: Interested in the construction of positive vocational identities among resettled refugees.

name: Karissa Beesley
description: Originally an entrepreneurship major, now interested in human behavior within the workplace.

description: Collaborator on research projects

name: Fiona Lee
title: Professor of Psychology
description: Studies culture, bicultural identities, and how multicultural experiences impact individuals. Research focuses on social behaviors within organizational and work settings.

name: Andrea Belgrade
title: Doctoral Candidate, University of Michigan
description: Examines how identity integration relates to intergroup relations.

name: Ram Mahalingam
title: Barger Leadership Institute Professor
description: Cultural psychologist, award-winning researcher, teacher, mentor, artist, and filmmaker. Research concerns nurturing a caring and compassionate workplace that treats its workers with dignity.

name: Sara McClelland
title: Professor of Women's & Gender Studies and Psychology
description: Studies how U.S. public policies shape people’s sexual and reproductive imaginations.

name: Emily Briggs
title: PhD Candidate
description: Work is centered in late life and takes a developmental approach to understand how people change throughout the life course. Interested in understanding how feelings of belonging and social relationships may change in later life.

name: Sarah Lapean
title: Doctoral Student
description: Research studies the emotions and moral evaluations that underlie sexual prejudice, and is particularly interested in how these factors affect sexual education in the United States.

name: Jay Seibold
title: Doctoral Student
description: Work investigates feminist epistemology with the purpose of developing measurements for intersectional identity. Specifically, explores the variance in how gender is conceptualized, embodied, and expressed by minority groups.

name: Julia Smoot
title: Doctoral Student
description: Work examines the factors that impact feelings of sexual guilt and how sexual guilt is measured in research.

name: Isis Settles
title: Professor of Psychology and Afroamerican and African Studies
description: Uses a feminist, intersectional framework to focus on experiences of unfair treatment and coping strategies for devalued social group members, especially Black women and men.

name: Eun Ju Son
title: Research Fellow
description: Working with Dr. Settles on the Faculty Epistemic Exclusion project.

name: R. Josiah Rosario
title: Research Fellow
description: Working with Dr. Settles on the CLIMBS UP project.

name: Jasmine Banks
title: Ph.D. candidate
description: Examines the intricacies of Black digital culture at the intersection of race, identity, and culture.

name: Eden Harrison
title: doctoral candidate
description: Research includes intersectional methodologies and deconstructing racist practices in academia.

name: Danielle Parra
title: doctoral candidate
description: Researches workplace conditions that affect women of color.

name: Joshua Ackerman
title: Professor of Psychology
description: Conducts research on evolutionary social psychology, investigating psychological mechanisms related to infectious disease, ecological features, and consumer decisions.

name: Nicole Li
description: Lab manager for the Evolutionary Social Psychology Lab.

name: Kaelyn Sabree
description: Second-year graduate student researching social motivation, social cognition, and the impact of the environment on thinking and behavior.

name: Savannah Adams
description: Fourth-year graduate student researching moral judgments, social contexts, and the impacts of computer-mediated communication.

name: David Dunning
title: Professor of Psychology
description: An experimental social psychologist, Dr. Dunning's work focuses primarily on the accuracy with which people view themselves and their peers.

name: Allison Earl
title: Associate Professor of Psychology
description: Investigates how people support one another through communication by shaping information, managing emotions, and signaling inclusion.

name: Susannah Cazaubon
description: Doctoral student in the Social Psychology department.

name: Amie M. Gordon
title: Professor (inferred)
description: Relationship researcher; focuses on conflict, understanding, appreciation, political differences in relationships, and the impact of events like the pandemic.

name: Christopher M. Barnes
title: Professor (inferred)
description: Research on sleep and work-life balance.

name: David B. Newman
title: Professor (inferred)
description: Research on socioeconomic factors, health, and happiness.

name: William B. Mendes
title: Professor (inferred)
description: Research on stress reduction, health, and happiness.

name: Elizabeth S. Diamond
title: Professor (inferred)
description: Research on feeling understood and appreciated in relationships.

name: Shinobu Kitayama
title: Robert B. Zajonc Collegiate Professor of Psychology
description: Our most recent work examines, among others, the self, cognition and emotion, norm psychology, and varieties of interdependence across the globe, with behavioral, neuroendocrine, neuroscience, and genetic and epigenetic methods.

name: Irene Melani
description: My research interests revolve broadly around understanding why and how cultural differences exist and manifest. Specifically, I am interested in the mechanisms underlying cultural variations in cognition and the ways individuals organize themselves within groups.

name: Tong Suo
description: My research interests revolve around the sense of self across time, namely autobiographical memory and future thinking, in-cultural contexts. I’m also interested in how cultural match and mismatch predicts well-being.

name: Amelie Rossmaier
description: My research interests revolve around culture and group dynamics. Specifically, I am focusing on how culture influences our motivation to conform and to trust in norms.

name: Yaxin Xiao
description: My research interests revolve around culture, social cognition, and neuroscience. Specifically, I am interested in exploring how culture learning on social cognition shapes our brain differently on both structural and activational levels. I am also interested in culture variations on the human physiological processes (e.g., neuroendocrine and immune systems).

name: Mohammadhasan (Hasan) Sharifian
description: My research revolves around culture and intergroup processes. Specifically, I am curious about the link between cultural tendencies and prejudice, conflict, and extremism. I am especially interested in focusing on understudied regions such as the Middle East and North Afri

name: Ethan Kross
title: Professor
description: His research examines how people can control their thoughts, feelings and behaviors to improve their lives.

name: Kate Schertz
description: She received her M.A. and Ph.D. in psychology from the University of Chicago where she studied how urban greenspace influenced thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.
